title: Why do people use premise incorrectly? - Quora

response.answer_text: You may be right that “premise” is sometimes used incorrectly, but there are times when “the premise of this book” is entirely correct. For example, you can say that the premise of Philip K Dick’s “The Man In The High Castle” is that the US lost WWII, and that Germany and Japan now run the country. In this case “premise” is correctly used to mean a proposition which forms the basis from which the work proceeds.
